chapter.title: 54 Peptostreptococcus, Finegoldia, Anaerococcus, Peptoniphilus, Parvimonas, Murdochiella, Veillonella, and Other Anaerobic Cocci*

sect1.title: 54 Peptostreptococcus, Finegoldia, Anaerococcus, Peptoniphilus, Parvimonas, Murdochiella, Veillonella, and Other Anaerobic Cocci*

para.phrase: ALIDA C. M. VELOO AND CRYSTAL N. JOHNSON

sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: Gram-positive anaerobic cocci (GPAC) belong to the Firmicutes phylum and have been known to most bacteriologists as peptococci or peptostreptococci. A history of changes in nomenclature and heavy synonym use often leads to confusion among associated taxa.Peptococcus species are only remotely related to other species of GPAC and are rarely cultured from human clinical specimens. Peptococcus niger was the sole remaining representative of this genus until Peptococcus simiae, of nonhuman origin, was added a few years ago (1). Most clinical isolates of GPAC were identified as species in the genus Peptostreptococcus; however, data obtained by molecular methods have led to extensive taxonomic changes over the past decades and also to the identification of new genera and species. Since 1998, the genus Peptostreptococcus has been divided into six novel genera (2–4). The genus Peptostreptococcus now consists of four species, of which Peptostreptococcus anaerobius and Peptostreptococcus stomatis (5) are the only two species that have been isolated from human specimens. Of the remaining two species, Peptostreptococcus canis has been isolated from the oral subgingival plaque obtained from the canine oral cavity (6). Peptostreptococcus magnus and Peptostreptococcus micros were assigned to two new genera, Finegoldia and Parvimonas, respectively (4, 7). For the remaining peptostreptococci, three genera were proposed: Anaerococcus, Peptoniphilus, and Gallicola (2). Anaerococcus has 14 valid species, including Anaerococcus hydrogenalis, A. lactolyticus, A. murdochii, A. octavius, A. prevotii, A. tetradius, and A. vaginalis and the newly described species A. senegalensis (8), A. degeneri (9), A. nagyae (10), A. pacaensis (11), A. provencensis (12), A. rubeinfantis (13), and A. porci (14). In addition to these validated species, seven nonvalid species have been described: “A. obesiensis” (15), “A. urinomassiliensis” (16), “A. jeddahensis” (17), “A. mediterraneensis” (18), “A. marasmi” (19), “A. vaginimassiliensis” (20), and “A. faecalis” (21).

Peptoniphilus has 18 valid species: P. asaccharolyticus, P. gorbachii, P. harei, P. indolicus, P. ivorii, P. lacrimalis, P. olsenii, P. methioninivorax (22), P. tyrrelliae (23), P. coxii (23), P. duerdenii (24), P. koenoeneniae (24), P. stercorisuis (25), P. timonensis (26), P. catoniae (27), P. lacydonensis (28), P. faecalis (29), and P. porci (14). The last two were isolated from pig intestinal microbiota.

As within the genusAnaerococcus, nonvalid species have also been described: “P. obesi” (30), “P. rhinitidis” (31), “P. mikwangii” (32), “P. grossensis” (33), “P. phoceensis” (34), “P. vaginalis” (35), “P. raoultii” (36), “P. duodeni” (37), “P. nemausus” (38), “P. pacaensis” (39), “P. urinimassiliensis” (40), and “P. senegalensis” (41). The fact that not all species are validated complicates the taxonomy. For example, “P. rhinitidis” was shown to be similar to P. lacydonensis, “P. senegalensis” to P. tyrrelliae, and “P. phoceensis” to P. timonensis (42). Within this chapter the names of the valid species are used. The nonvalid species “P. mikwangii” and “P. duodeni” appear to be similar to one another. Since “P. mikwangii” is listed in the List of Prokaryotic Names with Standing in Nomenclature (LPSN) and “P. duodeni” is not, the former is used in this chapter. Due to the constant changes in taxonomy, it is advised to regularly check the LPSN list (https://lpsn.dsmz.de/).

The genusGallicola contains only one species, Gallicola barnesae, which has not been reported from human specimens (2). The genus Fastidiosipila also contains only one species, Fastidiosipila sanguinis, which was isolated from human blood (43). Recently, three new GPAC genera were described: Murdochiella (44), Anaerosphaera (45), and Ezakiella (46). Currently Murdochiella consists of two valid species, M. asaccharolytica and M. vaginalis (44, 47), as does the genus Anaerosphaera: A. aminiphila and A. multitolerans (45, 48). The genus Ezakiella consists of three valid species: E. peruensis, E. coagulans, and E. massiliensis (46, 49, 50). To date, only M. asaccharolytica has been isolated from human clinical specimens.

Taxonomy of the other GPAC from human clinical specimens has also been under revision.Streptococcus parvulus was transferred to the genus Atopobium as Atopobium parvulum. Peptostreptococcus productus was reclassified in a newly proposed genus, Blautia, as Blautia producta (51); Peptostreptococcus saccharolyticus has been transferred to the genus Staphylococcus. Table 1 shows the changes in classification of GPAC species.

sect2.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE GROUP OF ORGANISMS
sect2.para: The organisms included in this chapter are obligately anaerobic, non-spore-forming, sometimes elongated cocci. The generaAnaerococcus, Anaerosphaera, Fastidiophila, Finegoldia, Gallicola, Murdochiella, Parvimonas, Peptococcus, Peptoniphilus, and Peptostreptococcus are Gram-positive, coccobacillary or occasionally coccoid cells. In Gram-stained preparations of pure cultures, cells vary in size from 0.3 to 2.0 μm and can be arranged in pairs, short chains, tetrads, small clusters, or irregular masses; most species are present as either chains or clumps. The addition of new species to the Peptoniphilus genus led to an amended genus description in which in general carbohydrates are not fermented and occasional growth under microaerophilic conditions occurs (42). Most species are proteolytic, with products of protein digestion serving as the principal energy source.

table.title: TABLE 1 Changes in classification of GPAC speciesa

sect2.para: aThe Gram-negative anaerobic cocci (GNAC), including the genera Veillonella, Acidaminococcus, Megasphaera, Anaeroglobus, and the recently described Negativicoccus, have been classified in a single family, the Acidaminococcaceae (60). Recently, several new species have been added to the genus Veillonella, which now consists of 15 species. Species recovered from human clinical specimens are V. atypica, V. montpellierensis (145), V. denticariosi (108), V. dispar, V. parvula, V. rogosae (146), V. tobetsuensis (147), V. seminalis (59), V. infantium (148), and V. nakazawae (149). V. alcalescens is a synonym for V. parvula (150). Species originating from animals are V. criceti, V. ratti, V. rodentium (150, 151), V. caviae (150), and V. magna (152). Besides Veillonella species, A. fermentans and A. intestini of the genus Acidaminococcus, M. elsdenii and M. micronuciformis of the genus Megasphaera, and A. geminatus of the genus Anaeroglobus have been isolated from human clinical samples.
bThe species is not validly accepted.

Two genera that are not or seldom encountered in human clinical specimens areSarcina and Coprococcus. The cell morphology of Sarcina differs from other GPAC due to their characteristic packets of eight cells which are able to produce spores. Sarcina ventriculi is the only species that has been isolated from clinical specimens so far. Coprococcus species have been isolated from human gastrointestinal samples and require special media for isolation (52). The genus Staphylococcus contains two notable species, Staphylococcus saccharolyticus and Staphylococcus aureus subsp. anaerobius, which initially grow under anaerobic conditions but become aerotolerant upon subculture. Strictly anaerobic Staphylococcus epidermidis is reported to be occasionally isolated from clinical specimens (53). The genera Veillonella, Acidaminococcus, Megasphaera, Anaeroglobus, and Negativicoccus are Gram-negative cocci. Cells vary in size from 0.3 to 2.5 μm. They characteristically occur in pairs, though single cells, masses, or chains may also occur. Carbohydrates are weakly fermented or not fermented, and gas is produced. Metabolic end products are the principal characteristics by which these genera can be differentiated.

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY
sect2.para: GPAC are part of the commensal microbiota of the human mouth, upper respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts, female genitourinary system, and skin (54). Parvimonas micra is usually considered to be the predominant species of GPAC in the oral microbiome. The skin microbiota also contains GPAC, with Finegoldia magna as the species identified most frequently, followed by P. asaccharolyticus. P. asaccharolyticus is reported to be frequently isolated from human clinical specimens; however, studies indicate that most of the clinical strains identified as P. asaccharolyticus in the past are in fact P. harei (55), which has the same biochemical features as P. asaccharolyticus and can be differentiated from P. asaccharolyticus only by its irregular colony and cell morphologies. Therefore, the incidence of P. asaccharolyticus in clinical material is potentially overestimated.

GPAC are also opportunistic pathogens and account for approximately one-third of anaerobic bacteria isolated from clinical specimens (52, 54). As the incidence of GPAC in clinical specimens continues to grow, so too does the importance of documenting their abundance, virulence factors, and patterns of antibiotic resistance. They can be isolated from a variety of sites, though predominantly from abscesses and infections of the skin and soft tissue, the mouth, bones, joints, and upper respiratory and female genital tracts. With increasing studies of GPAC as pathogens, certain species are being associated with specific types of infection. For example, F. magna is most commonly associated with infections of the skin, soft tissue, bone and joint infections. There is a strong association between F. magna isolated in pure culture from an infection and orthopedic procedures and postoperative wound infections (56). P. anaerobius and A. prevotii are the most common GPAC associated with infections of the abdominal cavity and female urogenital tract, whereas P. micra is mainly recognized as an oral pathogen. Complicated by taxonomic restructuring and their heterogeneous nature, this group of bacteria remains a critical area of study related to human health.

Gram-negative anaerobic cocci (GNAC) also form part of the oral, genitourinary, respiratory, and intestinal microbiota of humans (52). Veillonella species are part of the normal mouth and urogenital microbiome. They are found in greatest concentrations in saliva and on the surface of the tongue (57, 58). Veillonella species can also be found in the upper respiratory tract and intestine. Occasionally, Veillonella species have been isolated from sites of infection, where they are typically part of a mixed culture. V. seminalis has been primarily isolated from clinical samples originating from the genital tract, mainly semen, as part of a mixed culture (59). Several other Veillonella species originated from the oral microbiota of rodents. It can be hypothesized that these species can be encountered in bite infections caused by these animals. Negativicoccus succinivorans has been isolated from human skin or soft-tissue specimens (60). Acidaminococcus and Megasphaera species are part of the intestinal microbiota but may also be recovered from certain infections (61, 62).

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: GPAC are opportunistic pathogens; they can cause various infections involving all areas of the human body, ranging in severity from mild skin abscesses to more serious and life-threatening infections such as brain abscess, epidural abscess, bacteremia, endocarditis, necrotizing pneumonia, bone and joint infection, and septic abortion. The incidence of anaerobic cocci in pleuropulmonary infections such as lung abscess, necrotizing pneumonia, aspiration pneumonia, and empyema is approximately 40% (63, 64). Anaerobic cocci are also often isolated from skin and soft-tissue infections as well as a range of chronic and acute wound infections such as anaerobic streptococcal myonecrosis, progressive bacterial synergistic gangrene, necrotizing fasciitis, crepitant cellulitis, chronic burrowing ulcer, and synergistic necrotizing cellulitis (52, 65, 66). These are severe infections with mortality rates as high as 75%. Other infections in which anaerobic cocci have been recognized as significant pathogens are oral and dental infections, female genital tract infections, and intra-abdominal infections (67–69). GPAC are involved as pathogens in ear, nose, and throat infections, ocular infections, head and neck infections (including serious neck space infections), meningitis, pericarditis, bone and joint infections (including periprosthetic joint infections), breast abscess, urinary tract infections, and anorectal sepsis with and without anal fistula (70, 71).

Estimation of the clinical significance of anaerobic cocci isolated from clinical specimens is often difficult, partly due to their fastidiousness and thus difficulty to isolate. The polymicrobial nature of GPAC infections, in addition to inadequate classification, has most likely contributed to neglect the clinical significance of individual species of GPAC. Molecular methods and the introduction of matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) have led to improved identification of GPAC from various infections, resulting in better appreciation of their clinical importance. For example, La Scola et al. (72) recently identified GPAC in blood cultures and osteoarticular samples by use of MALDI-TOF MS, PCR, and 16S rRNA PCR/gene sequencing. Furthermore, a case of bacteremia caused by Finegoldia species was also recently reported by Rosenthal et al. (73). Using pyrosequencing, several studies have demonstrated that other than aerobic species, anaerobes including Peptoniphilus, Finegoldia, and Anaerococcus species are present in wound infections (74–78). Another interesting study indicated that when the microbiota from patients with chronic rhinosinusitis was identified with pyrosequencing, anaerobic genera like Peptoniphilus predominated, in contrast to Staphylococcus species, which were detected by traditional methods (79).

Mostly, GPAC are isolated from polymicrobial infections, but in some cases, the organisms are recovered in pure culture; this is the case mainly forF. magna, although other species, like P. anaerobius, P. asaccharolyticus, P. indolicus, P. micra, A. vaginalis, A. prevotii, and P. harei, also occur in pure culture (52, 54, 80).

F. magna is the most pathogenic and one of the most frequently isolated GPAC species in human clinical specimens. It has been isolated in pure culture from a variety of infections at various body sites. These include cases of endocarditis, meningitis, and pneumonia, some of which have been fatal (81). F. magna is most commonly associated with infections of the skin and soft tissue, with bone and joint infections, and with chronic wounds, including diabetic ulcers and pressure ulcers, but has also been isolated from cases of septic arthritis, prosthetic implant infections, breast abscesses, diabetic foot infections, and upper respiratory tract infections, such as sinusitis and otitis media. By culture-independent methods, F. magna was detected from patients with culture-negative endocarditis and periprosthetic joint infections (82, 83). More recently, F. magna has been implicated in a case of toxic shock syndrome (73). These reports suggest that the overall significance of F. magna as a pathogen is underestimated and that more accurate detection and identification of this bacterium might lead to an altered view of the frequency of F. magna in relation to certain clinical conditions. Several virulence factors have been described for F. magna, such as protein L, peptostreptococcal albumin-binding protein, SufA, and F. magna adhesion factor, as reviewed by Murphy and Frick (54). Recently, whole-genome sequencing has furthered understanding of the pathogenicity of this organism by elucidating both chromosomally encoded and mobile plasmid-mediated virulence factors (84). Seven sortases were encoded on a plasmid, and four on the chromosome. These extracellular transpeptidases catalyze the anchoring of cell wall proteins. The high number of sortases likely impacts the virulence of F. magna. In a recent study by Donelli et al. (85), F. magna was shown to have the ability to form biofilms, which could protect it from host immune defense as well as targeted antibiotic therapies. Additionally, F. magna has been shown to interact directly with human neutrophils, increasing the virulence and pathogenicity of this GPAC (86).

P. anaerobius is involved in polymicrobial infections, including abscess of the brain, ear, jaw, pleural cavity, pelvis, urogenital tract, external genitalia, abdominal regions, and nasal septum, as well as a range of acute and chronic wound infections (52, 54). It is one of the most common GPAC associated with infections of the abdominal cavity and female urogenital tract (52). P. anaerobius has also been isolated from endocarditis patients (87, 88). It is mostly associated with mixed-infection sites, but there have been some reports of isolation in pure culture (89–91). P. anaerobius has been associated with various oral infections, such as gingivitis and periodontitis, and is one of the species found most frequently in the root canals of teeth with periapical abscesses. More recently, a study by Long et al. (92) showed an association between P. anaerobius and colorectal carcinoma, whereby bacterial surface proteins adhere to receptors commonly found on cancer cell lines, leading to tumor proliferation and a proinflammatory response. P. stomatis, which was misidentified as P. anaerobius previously, is associated with infections of the human oral cavity, such as dentoalveolar abscesses and endodontic infections (5). This organism was detected in one-quarter of the cases from a large number of necrotic root canal samples (93). The clinical relevance of newly described Peptostreptococcus species is undefined.

P. micra is well recognized as an oral pathogen. Although it is considered a natural commensal of the oral cavity, elevated counts of this organism are associated with periodontal destruction. It is also commonly isolated from other oral infections, such as endodontic disease and peritonsillar infections. Recent advances in bacterial identification by molecular methods have confirmed the association of P. micra with oral infections (94). P. micra is not restricted to the oral cavity; it is often isolated in mixed anaerobic infections from different body sites, including a range of skin infections, wound infections, otitis media, sinus infections, pleural empyema, intra-abdominal infections, anorectal abscess, septicemia, gynecological infections, vertebral osteomyelitis, and periprosthetic joint infections.

The clinical importance of the generaPeptoniphilus and Anaerococcus is supported by use of molecular methods to analyze clinical samples. Peptoniphilus species such as P. harei, P. ivorii, and P. indolicus have been frequently found in samples derived from pressure ulcers (75). In addition to Peptoniphilus species, GPAC in general dominated these types of samples. Other studies using pyrosequencing reported high prevalences of Peptoniphilus species, F. magna, and Anaerococcus species in diabetic ulcers (74, 76) and Peptoniphilus species in chronic rhinosinusitis (79). A. prevotii is frequently recovered from clinical specimens derived from vaginal discharges and ovarian, peritoneal, sacral, and lung abscesses (95, 96). In a recent survey of the bacterial diversity in biofilms of various wound types, A. lactolyticus and A. vaginalis were identified among the predominant species in diabetic foot ulcers and pressure ulcers (74). A. vaginalis and A. prevotii were also identified after recovery from blood cultures by MALDI-TOF MS and 16S rRNA PCR/gene sequencing (72). As with the newly described Peptostreptococcus species, the clinical relevance of new Peptoniphilus and Anaerococcus species is unknown.

GNAC account for a small percentage of anaerobic cocci isolated from human specimens. They are part of the commensal microbiota of the oropharynx, gastrointestinal tract, and female genital tract.Veillonella species have been occasionally isolated from sites of infection, where they are typically part of a mixed culture (97). Risk factors for Veillonella infection include periodontal disease, immunodeficiency, injection drug use, and premature birth. Very rarely, Veillonella species have been the only etiologic agents identified in serious infections such as meningitis, osteomyelitis, prosthetic joint infection, pleuropulmonary infection, bacteremia, and endocarditis (98). The specific role of Veillonella species as pathogens is unclear, and little is known about their virulence.

The variety of infections in which anaerobic cocci are involved has been reviewed and summarized (52, 54). Although the spectrum of infections has remained relatively unchanged since the extensive review by Murdoch in 1998 (52), the prevalence of these organisms as pathogens is increasing.

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF CLINICAL SPECIMENS
sect2.para: Most GPAC isolated from human clinical material are not extremely oxygen sensitive. However, specimens suspected of harboring anaerobic cocci should be collected, transported, and stored by methods outlined inchapter 53 of this Manual.

sect2.title: DIRECT EXAMINATION
sect2.para: Direct examination of specimens frequently provides the most rapid indication of microbial infection. A variety of microscopic, immunologic, and molecular techniques have been developed for direct examination of GPAC.

Microscopic morphology of the anaerobic cocci is varied.P. anaerobius and B. producta are large coccobacilli that form chains, especially in broth cultures. Other anaerobic cocci, such as A. tetradius, A. prevotii, and F. magna (99), have cells greater than 0.6 μm in diameter that occur in pairs and clusters and may resemble staphylococcal cells. P. micra cells are less than 0.7 μm in diameter and occur in packets and short chains; difference in cell size has been used as a characteristic to distinguish P. micra and F. magna.

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: Routinely used anaerobic plate media, such asBrucella, Columbia, or Schaedler agar base supplemented with 5% sheep blood, vitamin K1 (1 mg/liter), and hemin (5 mg/liter), support the growth of these microorganisms. The usual procedures for anaerobes should be followed. Many of these organisms require high moisture content for optimal growth, so fresh media should be used. Laboratories unable to prepare their own media may wish to consider the use of commercially prepared, prereduced, anaerobically sterilized blood agar (Anaerobe Systems, USA; bioMérieux, France; HiMedia, India). These media have an extended shelf life of up to 6 months and yield results comparable to or better than those obtained with fresh media.

GPAC are heterogeneous; a single medium is unlikely to support growth of all representatives and be reasonably selective. Turng et al. (100) described Parvimonas micra medium, a selective and differential medium for P. micra that contains colistin-nalidixic acid agar (Difco, Detroit, MI), supplemented with glutathione and lead acetate. Strains of P. micra can use the reduced form of glutathione to form hydrogen sulfide, which reacts with lead acetate to form a black precipitate under the colony. Tween 80 supplementation (0.02%) of media may improve growth of some GPAC.

Gutierrez de Ferro et al. (57) tested different media for recovery of Veillonella species from saliva samples and concluded that a selective medium for Veillonella with vancomycin and laked blood, stimulating red fluorescence of Veillonella colonies, yielded the greatest recovery of Veillonella species.

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: Some GPAC, particularly strains ofP. asaccharolyticus, decolorize readily with Gram stain and can be confused with Gram-negative anaerobes such as Veillonella. GPAC can be distinguished from GNAC by special potency disks (vancomycin, 5 μg; kanamycin, 1,000 μg; and colistin, 10 μg). The cell morphology of older cultures of GPAC can be irregular, with coccobacillary and rodlike forms. It is also important to distinguish GPAC from microaerophilic organisms, such as strains of Streptococcus species.

P. anaerobius is the only GPAC that gives a zone of inhibition of ≥12 mm around a 5% sodium polyanethol sulfonate (SPS) disk. P. micra also exhibits a zone of inhibition with SPS, although the zone is usually <12 mm. It is the authors’ experience that P. ivorii can also give an inhibition zone of >12 mm; however, it can easily be differentiated from P. micra and P. anaerobius due to its different cell morphology. P. ivorii forms large cocci, while P. micra shows small cocci and P. anaerobius appears as oval cells in chains. Most P. anaerobius strains form distinctive colonies on enriched blood agar; they are 1 mm in diameter after 24 hours, appear gray with slightly raised off-white centers, and possess a distinctive sweet odor (101). P. micra and F. magna can be readily distinguished by a combination of colonial morphology and proteolytic enzyme profiles, supported by Gram-stained cell morphology to assess cell size. An anaerobic coccus with a milky halo around the colonies and small cells (<0.6 μm) can be presumptively identified as P. micra (101). F. magna cells are larger than those of most GPAC. Only A. vaginalis and P. ivorii form larger cells. They can be differentiated by enzymatic tests for proteolytic activity such as proline arylamidase, phenylalanine arylamidase, and tyrosine arylamidase (7).

Cells ofP. harei vary in size (diameter, 0.5 to 1.5 μm) and shape (circular, oval, or elliptical), whereas cells of P. asaccharolyticus are more uniform. Since P. asaccharolyticus and P. harei share the same biochemical features, this is the only characteristic to differentiate them from one another. Colonies of 5-day cultures on enriched blood agar are approximately 1 mm in diameter, entire, flat, and translucent.

Similar observations were made forA. prevotii and A. tetradius, which were reported as common species of GPAC in human clinical material in early surveys. However, nucleic acid studies indicate that they are very heterogeneous. Again, in the 2003 study based on 16S rRNA gene PCR/sequencing, Song et al. (102) indicated that a large percentage of organisms identified as A. prevotii or A. tetradius were actually strains of A. vaginalis. Strictly defined strains of A. prevotii and A. tetradius are likely only occasionally recovered from clinical specimens. The activity of pyroglutamic acid arylamidase might be useful for differentiation of A. prevotii and A. tetradius; however, distinctions cannot be generalized because insufficient numbers of strains of each species have been reliably identified. A. prevotii and A. tetradius can be distinguished from other recognized species of GPAC by production of α-glucosidase and β-glucuronidase. Strains of other saccharolytic GPAC, such as A. vaginalis and A. lactolyticus, can be differentiated by their enzyme profiles.

Table 2 summarizes the differential characteristics of GPAC. Species lacking phenotypic data mostly used to identify GPAC are not mentioned in the table. Identification is based on phenotypic tests that can be performed in most diagnostic laboratories. Most of the information presented here relates to the phenotypic characteristics of strains typically isolated from humans.

Several identification systems, such as the Rapid ID 32A (bioMérieux, Marcy l’Etoile, France) and RapID ANA II (Remel, Inc., Lenexa, KS) systems, are available commercially for the identification of anaerobes. The authors’ most recent evaluation of the Rapid ID 32A kit for identification of GPAC, in comparison with 16S rRNA PCR/gene sequencing identification, showed that the system is good for accurate identification ofP. micra, P. anaerobius, and F. magna. Often, P. asaccharolyticus is included in these systems; however, this species has the same phenotypic features as P. harei (54). An identification of P. asaccharolyticus should therefore be interpreted as P. asaccharolyticus/harei.

Veillonella, Acidaminococcus, and Megasphaera species comprise the principal genera of GNAC. Identification of Veillonella to the species level remains uncertain and inconvenient owing to a lack of conventional phenotypic and biochemical discriminating tests. Table 3 contains a key for differentiating the genera of GNAC (60).

sect1.title: Molecular Methods
sect1.para: The introduction of molecular-based methods for bacterial identification enabled a paradigm shift in the early 1990s. 16S rRNA gene-based methods have been used for identifying clinically important GPAC. Monoplex or multiplex PCR and 16S rRNA gene-based methods were developed for rapid identification of clinically significant GPAC isolates from clinical samples (80, 94, 103–106). Lin et al. (107) developed an oligonucleotide array for clinically important anaerobes, including A. prevotii, A. tetradius, F. magna, P. asaccharolyticus, P. anaerobius, and P. micra. A disadvantage of the methods mentioned above is that only species included in the method are identified, with new species missing.

Within the genusVeillonella, different species have a low 16S rRNA gene sequence variation between each other (108, 109), which makes PCR methods based on the 16S rRNA gene unsuitable for species identification. Marchandin et al. (110) used the heat shock protein gene dnaK, which shows higher interspecies variation than the 16S rRNA gene, for differentiation of Veillonella species. Beighton et al. (111) reported using rpoB gene sequencing for identifying Veillonella species isolated from tongue samples; subsequently, a two-step PCR procedure was developed for identification of recognized oral Veillonella species (104). Recently, Aujoulat et al. (59) developed a PCR assay targeting the citrate synthase gene (gltA) of Veillonella species. According to these three studies, the three housekeeping genes rpoB, dnaK, and gltA are helpful to differentiate among the Veillonella species.

sect1.title: MALDI-TOF MS Method
sect1.para: More recently, MALDI-TOF MS was introduced and broadly accepted as a new diagnostic gold standard for microbial species identification. The influence of different factors (incubation time, sample preparation, and exposure to oxygen) on the quality of a spectrum of anaerobic bacteria has been studied by Veloo et al. (112). Spotting of bacteria should be performed on the same day (<24 hours of exposure to oxygen) and by an experienced individual; MALDI-TOF MS analysis should be performed after 48 hours of incubation; and on-target extraction with 70% formic acid should be performed on Gram-positive anaerobic bacteria. By constructing a database using commonly isolated strains of GPAC as a reference, Veloo et al. (113) were able to identify clinical isolates by MALDI-TOF MS with results comparable to those of other identification methods. This method is a rapid and inexpensive alternative to molecular identification with equivalent accuracy. Additionally, bacterial identification by MALDI-TOF MS is more cost-effective than by conventional methods. The commercial databases that accompany a MALDI-TOF MS system mostly contain reference spectra representing the most common encountered GPAC. Veloo et al. (114) showed that by optimizing the Biotyper MALDI-TOF MS database, using well-characterized clinical isolates of species (valid and nonvalid) under-represented or not represented in the database, the rate of reliable species identification increased from 53.6% to 82.1%. Studies evaluating the VITEK MS database for the identification of GPAC are to our knowledge not published. The use of MALDI-TOF MS enables identification of less common species, which would be missed by phenotypic methods, and nonvalid species. This makes it possible to assess their clinical relevance. However, it should be kept in mind that the MALDI-TOF MS can only identify species represented in the database used.
Whether MALDI-TOF MS can be used to identify certainVeillonella species requires further research.

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITIES
sect2.para: New information regarding the antimicrobial susceptibilities of individual GPAC is increasing due to the improvement in classification and identification. For example, in a recent study, the susceptibilities of 115 GPAC isolates, representing 14 species, which were identified by genetic approaches, were determined for 14 antibiotics (115). However, new information is sparse compared with information available for other anaerobic species. It is also difficult to compare new data to other published data because previous studies failed to provide results for specific species, opting instead to combine data for the group.

table.title: TABLE 2 Biochemical features of different GPAC speciesa

sect2.para: a Data mainly from the work of Murdoch (7) and Song et al. (153). Biochemical features of the species are derived from the original publication describing the species. Abbreviations and symbols: IND, indole; URE, urease; ALP, alkaline phosphatase; ADH, arginine dihydrolase; α-GAL, α-galactosidase; β-GAL, β-galactosidase; α-GLU, α-glucosidase; β-GUR, β-glucuronidase; ArgA, arginine arylamidase (AMD); ProA, proline AMD; LeuA, leucine AMD; PyrA, pyroglutamyl AMD; TyrA, tyrosine AMD; HisA, histidine AMD; GGA, glutamyl glutamic acid AMD; SerA, serine AMD; ND, not determined; −, >90% negative; +, >90% positive; v, variable; w+, weak positive; w–, weak negative.

b Nonvalid species. For most nonvalid species, biochemical features are omitted or only partly described; these include: “A. obesiensis,” “A. urinomassiliensis,” “A. mediterraneensis,” P. methioninivorax, “P. mikwangii,” “P. urinimassiliensis,” “P. pacaensis,” “P. raoultii,” and “P. vaginalis.” For A. porci, A rubeinfantis, and P. porci, although valid, biochemical features are not described. Also, the biochemical features of Anaerosphaera aminiphila are not described.

entry.phrase: Amino acids as the main source of energyc

sect2.para: aModified from the work of Marchandin et al. (36). Abbreviations and symbols: A, acetic acid; P, propionic acid; L, lactic acid; B, butyric acid; V, valeric acid; C, caproic acid; iB, isobutyric acid; iV, isovaleric acid.

bGlucose fermentation tests were performed with prereduced, anaerobically sterilized (PRAS) PYG broth tubes (Anaerobe Systems, Morgan Hill, CA). The PRAS tubes were inoculated from an actively growing broth culture (without carbohydrate). A pH of ≤5.5 in the PRAS tubes was interpreted as positive, 5.6 to 5.8 as weakly positive, and ≥5.9 as negative fermentation.
cCarbohydrates are not fermented for most of the species; amino acids are used as energy sources.
dParentheses indicate that these compounds are produced in variable amounts.

Antibiotics such as penicillins, clindamycin, and metronidazole are generally considered to be active against GPAC. However, studies indicate that susceptibilities are variable between various species (116–120) and should continue to be studied, in order to monitor for potential increasing antibiotic resistance of GPAC. Most evidence suggests that P. asaccharolyticus, F. magna, and P. micra are usually susceptible to penicillins, although Wren (99) reported 16% and 8% resistance among isolates of F. magna and P. micra, respectively. In other studies, F. magna showed lower rates of resistance of 10 to 20% to clindamycin, metronidazole, and penicillin, with higher rates of resistance (>20%) to erythromycin and tetracycline (99, 117, 118, 121–124); however, two other studies reported a higher prevalence of resistance to clindamycin (119, 125). Brazier et al. (117) suggest that A. prevotii is resistant to tetracycline, erythromycin, and clindamycin; the study also found that the highest percentage of overall resistance detected among GPAC was 41.6% resistance to tetracycline, followed by 27.4% resistance to erythromycin. Among GPAC as a group, 7.1% of isolates were resistant to penicillin and clindamycin, and 3.5% were resistant to amoxicillin-clavulanate. Other studies have shown resistance of A. prevotii, isolated from diabetic foot infections, to clindamycin, levofloxacin, and ceftazidime (126, 127). Clinical isolates of A. murdochii (six) were reported to be resistant to colistin, two to kanamycin, and one to clindamycin, with three showing intermediate resistance to penicillin; in the same study, P. gorbachii showed resistance to clindamycin (128). A recent study reported that P. coxii isolates were resistant to doxycycline, with 29% resistant to moxifloxacin and clindamycin, and all isolates of P. tyrrelliae were susceptible to doxycycline but resistant to moxifloxacin, with 25% being resistant to clindamycin (23). Clindamycin resistance in P. asaccharolyticus and P. micra has also been reported (118, 127, 129). There are indications that clindamycin resistance in P. harei is increasing, from 0% (115) to 21% (130). Since P. harei has been misidentified as P. asaccharolyticus in the past, only scarce data are available on the antibiotic profile of this species. It is of importance to note that recently a multi-drug-resistant F. magna strain was reported by Shilnikova et al. (131). A study by the European Study Group on Anaerobic Infections (ESGAI) showed that the antimicrobial susceptibility profile of GPACs differs by genus and country (132). This emphasizes the importance of performing regular antibiotic susceptibility testing on clinical GPAC isolates.

Even less research has been performed on the presence of resistance genes in GPAC. In 2004, Theron et al. (133) reported on the presence of the metronidazole resistance gene nimB in GPAC. nimB was encountered in 34% of the tested isolates (MIC, ≥0.5 mg/liter), among them two highly resistant F. magna isolates. Tran et al. (134) detected resistance genes in anaerobic bacteria isolated from intra-abdominal infections. Among the anaerobic cocci (including Veillonella species), 16% harbored ermF. No other resistance genes were encountered. The introduction of whole-genome sequencing techniques is revealing mobile genetic elements which might be present in anaerobic bacteria, such as the presence of a Tn916-like transposon in Peptoniphilus isolates (42).

In general, GPAC are more susceptible to β-lactams/β-lactamase inhibitors, cephalosporins, carbapenems, and chloramphenicol than to penicillins, clindamycin, and metronidazole (135). Cephalosporins are usually, but not always, active, and carbapenems are reliably active. Several studies (99, 136, 137) have indicated that first-generation quinolones, such as ciprofloxacin, have only moderate activity. Useful references are available regarding the activity against anaerobes for ceftobiprole (126, 138), oritavancin (129), daptomycin (139), dalbavancin (127), tigecycline (140), and linezolid (141). P. anaerobius has also been shown to be reliably susceptible to oritavancin (129).

Resistance rates forP. stomatis and P. anaerobius are different (119). P. anaerobius sensu lato exhibits some resistance to amoxicillin, amoxicillin-clavulanate (3/30 isolates resistant), cefoxitin (2/30 isolates resistant), azithromycin, and moxifloxacin (1/30 isolates resistant), with no resistance found in 31 isolates of P. stomatis.

Veillonella species show resistance to tetracycline, erythromycin, gentamicin, and kanamycin and are susceptible to penicillin, cephalothin, and clindamycin. Resistance is intermediate for chloramphenicol and lincomycin (142). However, in a recent publication by Ready et al. (143), 64% of the Veillonella isolated from plaque samples of healthy children showed resistance to penicillin and 39% to ampicillin. High resistance rates (55.5%) to penicillin were also reported by Marchand-Austin et al. (144). In a study by Veloo et al. (130), all Veillonella isolates obtained from human clinical specimens were susceptible to amoxicillin, amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, clindamycin, and metronidazole.

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Because anaerobic bacteriology is time-consuming, several interim reports are desirable. The initial report should give Gram stain results as well as relevant bacterial and human cell morphologies. The relative quantities of different organisms seen in the smear give a good overall impression of specimen quality, the nature of the polymicrobial infection, and the relative importance of each organism. In general, bacteria that are predominant, virulent, and resistant to antimicrobial agents should be given the greatest attention. Bacteria present in pure culture or in large numbers are likely of importance, as are organisms recovered in multiple cultures and isolated from normally sterile sites. Furthermore, Gram stain results can guide the laboratory in choosing media for optimal recovery of the predicted organisms. Finally, given the physiologically diverse nature of this group, modern DNA-based sequencing technologies or MALDI-TOF MS should be used to determine bacterial identities quickly and accurately, where possible.

The significance of finding anaerobic Gram-positive and -negative cocci in clinical specimens depends on the specimen and the likelihood that it was contaminated by microbiota of the skin or mucous membranes. Hence, interpretation of culture results is largely dependent on the nature and quality of the specimen submitted to the laboratory. In order to further our understanding of GPAC and GNAC, it is urged that findings informing clinical relevance be shared to improve epidemiological associations, that new taxa be validly published in order to maintain clarity within this robust clade, and that a suitable identification approach be used to underpin the heterologous nature of this important group of organisms.
This chapter contains information presented by Yuli Song and Sydney M. Finegold inchapter 51 of the 11th edition of this Manual.
